Even under conservative assumptions, the downside appears limited (-9% IRR) relative to the upside potential in the base case (25-28% IRR) and bull case (50-70% IRR).

Conclusion

Duolingo is a global market leader with a capital-light business model that has demonstrated premium metrics since their IPO in 2021 - revenue has grown at a 43% CAGR, gross margins have remained above 70%, and free cash flow margins have expanded from 5% to 35%.

Shares are down more than 80% from their 2025 high due to investor concerns around AI disruption risk and near-term growth moderation. I believe both concerns are overstated. Duolingo is well placed to integrate AI into their platform and is making appropriate long-term decisions needed to sustain user growth to 2028.

When high-quality compounders temporarily fall out of favour due to short-term factors, long-term investors are paid to be patient. After selling a third of my position in Duolingo in June 2025 at a share price of over $510, I am adding aggressively to my Duolingo position during this sell-off.

data.title: Omnicom Group: Value Hiding In Plain Sight At Under 8x Earnings With Accelerated Buybacks
data.description:
Introduction

When it comes to Omnicom Group (OMC), I've been bullish on the stock for close to a year. Impacted by the high-interest rate environment, OMC has been going through massive changes, which I think will benefit the company long-term.

Despite the price rally after their buyback announcement, the advertising giant still trades at less than 8x earnings, presenting an attractive buying opportunity for long-term investors. You also get paid an attractive yield of over 4% while you wait.

At the current price, I believe Omnicom Group is a great value play that's likely to see at least $100 per share by the end of 2026. In this article, I discuss their latest earnings, fundamentals, and why I believe this stock is a bargain at the current price.

Previous Buy Thesis

I last covered Omnicom Group back in October in an article titled: A Cheap, AI Beneficiary With A 4%+ Yield & Massive Upside Potential.

At a multiple of less than 10x and a yield over 4%, OMC offered strong upside to their price target of $148.65 at the end of 2027. Since then, the stock has been somewhat volatile but is up modestly since my last coverage.

The S&P (SP500) has also been volatile but is up close to 2%, compared to 1.56% for OMC. During their Q3 earnings, OMC reported mixed results with a revenue miss due to declines in some of their segments. But their anticipated merger, expected to create synergies, strong balance sheet, and a well-covered dividend, were reasons I remained bullish.

Another Mixed Report, But Solid YoY Growth

Omnicom Group reported their Q4 earnings and saw a sizable miss on their bottom line. EPS amounted to $2.59, missing analysts' estimates by $0.35. Revenue amounted to $5.53 billion.

Despite the sizable miss, both EPS & revenue managed to see growth year-over-year. EPS grew from $2.41 the year prior, while revenue was up from $4.32 billion.

In total, EPS grew from $8.06 to $8.65, while their top line increased from approximately $15.7 billion to $17.3 billion. Their performance was driven by higher organic growth from the prior year.

Organic growth totaled 9.3%, up from 5.2% in 2024. This was led by higher growth in their Media & Advertising segment, up 14.9% compared to 7.8%. Experiential growth was up 19% compared to 15.4% last year.

Precision Marketing was up from 3.8% to 8.6%. Healthcare turned positive, up 2.5% vs being down 0.4% in 2025. It's likely lower base rates also played a role in OMC's performance.

Omnicom also likely benefitted from the successful closing of their Interpublic Group acquisition. As part of the portfolio repositioning, OMC's management exited non-performing assets.

These were identified as having approximately $2.5 billion in annual revenue. And management stated they plan to exit the remaining underperforming assets in the next 12 months.

Speaking of the IPG acquisition, OMC closed on this 3 months ago. And previously, management stated this was expected to be accretive to their bottom line in the first year. They also mentioned this was expected to save $750 million in costs.

After earnings, management doubled this to $1.5 billion and announced a $5 billion share repurchase program. And this caused the share price to rally. Synergies are expected over the course of the next 30 months. For 2026, they are expected to realize $900 million in cost savings.

OMC also announced a $2.5 billion accelerated buyback program. And I expect management to take advantage of the share price and exhaust this in the coming quarters. As a result, this should lead to strong earnings growth, thus positively impacting the share price long-term.

Well-Covered 3.5% Yield

Besides lowering costs, lower base rates should also benefit OMC as investors rotate back into the market looking for higher yields. Back in November, Omnicom Group announced a 14.3% dividend increase to $0.80 per share.

This was the first dividend increase since 2021. This, and their buyback program, should give investors confidence in their ability to see solid growth going forward.

The dividend was also well-covered by cash flows. For 2025, free cash flow grew from $1.96 billion to $2.23 billion. Net free cash flow amounted to $1.677 billion, while dividends for the year amounted to roughly $550 million.

This gives OMC a very conservative payout ratio of 33%, and plenty of room for future acquisitions, buybacks, and dividend increases. Going forward, I suspect dividend increases to continue, likely in the high single-digit to double-digit range.

Strong Balance Sheet

Because of the IPG acquisition, debt increased from $6 billion to $9.1 billion. As a result, leverage increased from 0.7x to 3.1x. For comparison, this was higher than both peers WPP plc (WPP) and Publicis Groupe S.A. (PUBGY), whose leverage ratios were 2.0x and 1.0x, respectively.

Omnicom's net debt stood at $2.23 billion. But liquidity was robust with roughly $6.9 billion in cash & cash equivalents and $3.5 billion undrawn on their revolver.

The upcoming debt was solidly staggered, with $1.4 billion due this year and a weighted-average interest rate of 3.6%. The rest of their debt was very manageable until 2030.

Because of their strong financial position, I anticipate management aggressively deleveraging in 2026 and beyond. So, for those worried about the IPG acquisition and how it impacts OMC's balance sheet, the advertising giant remains in a comfortable position.

Solid Growth Expected Going Forward

Analysts anticipate solid earnings growth going forward for OMC, with a CAGR of 14% over the next 5 years. While this may be a bit optimistic, I do foresee the company averaging high single-digit to double-digit growth for the foreseeable future. And this is due to divestitures, acquisition synergies, lower base rates, and buybacks.

Massive Upside Potential

Using their expected earnings of $11.14 for 2026, this gives Omnicom Group a forward P/E of just 7.42x, signaling the stock could be massively undervalued. This is also significantly below their 5-year average of 11.86x.

Another indicator that they could be massively undervalued is their PEG ratio of just 0.47x. If the advertising giant manages to see high single-digit to double-digit growth as I expect, I see them potentially re-rating higher, likely in the 12x-15x range in the next 2 to 3 years.

Wall Street currently has a price target of $100.50, more than 21% upside from the current price. If interest rates decline as expected and we manage to dodge a recession, I see the share price above $100 potentially by the end of the year.

According to F.A.S.T. Graphs, using their normal multiple of 14.48x, which I think is very reasonable for a company of their caliber, Omnicom appears massively undervalued here with a price target of $207.54 by the end of 2028.

Risks & Conclusion

Because of their business model, Omnicom is highly impacted by a weakening economy. The labor market has been experiencing weakening in recent months.

Due to most of their revenue coming from media & advertising, the stock is highly susceptible to businesses cutting costs.

This makes them riskier. But at a forward P/E of less than 8x, I believe downside is minimal unless the economy takes a turn for the worse.

They could also see impacts from AI down the line as businesses may use this to do their own advertising.

But Omnicom's bright outlook, well-covered 3.5% yield, robust cash flows, and suppressed share price make them a potential bargain with massive capital appreciation.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Sell Alert: 3 REITs I Expect To Cut Their Dividend
data.description:
During the past few weeks, I have written several articles reaffirming why I remain very bullish on REITs (VNQ) and invest a large portion of my portfolio in them.

Contrary to many, I think that the AI revolution still remains underhyped and will cause severe disruption and value destruction across a wide range of businesses over the coming years as it destroys barriers to entry, invites new competition, and ultimately hurts profitability.

The market has just begun to realize this, and it has caused the shares of some companies to sell off. This includes SaaS, professional services, trucking, white-collar infrastructure, and lots of cyclical consumer-facing businesses.

But guess what sector is resilient to the ravages caused by AI:

Real estate investment trusts, or REITs (VNQ) in short.

Real asset-based businesses are the exception.

They are the ultimate anti-AI asset class because most of them cannot be disrupted. You simply cannot replicate more land, building permits, financing, or construction materials with an AI model. You also cannot replace having a roof over your head.

Moreover, I expect AI to be highly deflationary and eventually bring much lower interest rates, potentially even a return to near-0% rates, which would be very bullish for REITs, given that they're today trading at historically low valuations due to the surge in interest rates of 2022/2023.

So overall, I'm very bullish on REITs.

However, this does not mean that I like every single one of them.

REITs, like other asset classes, include some good, some bad, and some truly ugly companies. Being selective is key if you want to maximize your risk-adjusted returns, and that starts by avoiding REITs that are likely to cut their dividend.

In what follows, I'm going to highlight three popular high-yielding REITs that I would avoid because they're at high risk of cutting their dividend in the near term:

Chiron Real Estate: Heavy Leverage and Short Debt Maturities

Chiron Real Estate (XRN) is popular among high-yield-seeking individual investors, and it's easy to understand why.

The REIT focuses on healthcare properties like medical office buildings, which benefit from the rapidly aging population and generate recession-resistant cash flows.

It also has five years left on its leases on average, and its tenants enjoy a 4.4x rent coverage ratio, which seems to indicate that its tenants are profitable and can easily cover rent payments.

Even then, it offers an 8.3% dividend yield, which is fully covered by FFO with a 73% payout ratio.

The REIT also already reduced its dividend once in 2025, and this appears to be reassuring many investors, who then conclude that they already cut the dividend and are therefore unlikely to cut it again.

Yet, that's exactly what I expect.

I actually predicted the divided cut of 2025 in a separate article that you can read by clicking here.

Most of it remains relevant today. They gained some time by reducing the dividend, but I think that they didn't cut it enough.

The problem is that the REIT has a lot of leverage. Its debt-to-EBITDA is 6.2x, and they still have some preferred equity on top of that.

Moreover, their average debt term is only about four years, on average, so they will face major near-term refinancing needs, and given that their current interest rate is only about 3.7%, they will face much higher interest expense.

This will then pressure their cash flow and lead to a surge in their payout ratio.

If everything goes perfectly to plan and interest rates decline from here, they may get lucky and still avoid a cut.

But what investors need to remember here is that Chiron Real Estate focuses primarily on riskier, higher cap rate healthcare properties, often located in secondary or tertiary markets with non-credit tenants. It has historically gotten a near 8% cap rate on average on its acquisitions, and you just don't get such high cap rates without taking risks. The REIT has suffered some tenant bankruptcies and likely will again in the future.

And given the state of its balance sheet, I think that it would take only a small setback for it to be forced to cut its dividend once again. There's little room for error when you operate with so much leverage and short debt maturities.

Finally, I would note that the REIT just recently completed a rebranding, changing its name from Global Medical REIT to Chiron Real Estate.

This, on its own, of course, does not suggest a dividend cut, but companies will often push for major strategy and capital allocation changes before rebranding to mark a new, fresh start.

I think that a dividend cut is a high risk here, and for this reason, we prefer to invest in some of its peers, like Sila Realty Trust (SILA) at High-Yield Landlord.

Global Net Lease: Poor Track Record and Heavy Exposure to Troubled Assets

Global Net Lease (GNL) has surged a lot lately, and it has bulls celebrating.

But if I owned the stock, I would take advantage of this recent rally to sell and move on to something else before the company possibly cuts its dividend again.

The market is getting excited about the company's recent transformation, selling net lease offices to reinvest in net lease industrial assets, even as it reduced leverage and internalized its management.

Those are all great steps, and I agree with the market in that sense.

With a forward AFFO per share guidance of $0.96, its $0.76 dividend also appears to be well-covered and sustainable, and yet, it still yields nearly 8%.

Note that I used the word "appear" here because I actually don't think that it will be sustained for very long.

The REIT has cut its dividend many times in the past, and I have predicted a few of those cuts via separate articles.

And despite all the recent progress, I still think that the REIT will have to cut it down even more for two reasons:

First, its balance sheet remains stretched with a 7.2x debt-to-EBITDA. When you include its preferred equity, it rises closer to 8x.

Moreover, its debt maturities are short at just about three years, with significant maturities coming its way in 2027 and 2028.

Second, the REIT still generates today about a quarter of its rental revenue from net lease office buildings, and those properties only have about 4.5 years left on their leases.

I have previously explained why I think that these properties are a disaster. They still generate a steady income while they have years left on the leases, but I think that they face significant maturities as leases expire, and it will be very costly and difficult, if even possible, to release some of these properties.

Office vacancy rates are at an all-time high of more than 20%, and these older single-tenant office buildings are the worst impacted by the shift to hybrid work settings. With AI now further reducing the need for white-collar labor, I expect things to only get worse in the near term.

The balance of power is clearly on the side of the tenants, and this spells trouble for a REIT that still generates 26% of its rental income from such potentially unsustainable assets, even as its own balance sheet is heavily leveraged as well.

GNL may manage to delay a dividend cut for a while, but I expect them to eventually be forced to cut it again. It would be prudent for them to do it as soon as possible to retain more cash flow for deleveraging and to accelerate their transformation away from these troubled assets.

Finally, I want to remind you that this is the track record of the REIT: It's one of the most challenged in the entire REIT sector, repeatedly diluting shareholders with ill-timed capital raises, which later led to many dividend cuts:

I would sell and move on to other high-quality net lease REITs like NNN REIT (NNN), which also offer good value for money in today's market.

Community Healthcare Trust: Stubbornly Holding onto an Unsustainable Payout Ratio

Community Healthcare Trust (CHCT) is another popular choice for high-yield-seeking investors, as it offers a near 11% dividend yield, owns recession-resistant healthcare properties, and its management appears to be highly focused on paying a steadily growing dividend.

They have a great track record of that:

They once again increased the dividend by 0.5% earlier this month, which would seem to indicate the dividend is safe.

But you can only do that for so long when your balance sheet is stretched and your dividend is poorly covered.

Their current payout ratio is about 85% of their AFFO, even as their debt-to-EBITDA is at about 7x.

Just like in the case of Chiron Real Estate, the dividend could be sustained as long as they don't suffer any hiccups, but it leaves little room for error, and it would only take a small lease default for it to come under severe pressure.

Closing Note

Not all REIT dividends are sustainable, and if you want to avoid future dividend cuts, you must be very selective and focus on REITs with strong balance sheets that leave enough room for error.

Occasional setbacks are inevitable, and you don't want to be in a position in which a tiny misstep costs you your dividend and leads to sharp losses.

We aren't perfect, of course, as our recent losses on Alexandria Real Estate (ARE) demonstrate, but by avoiding most dividend cuts, we have added considerable alpha to our portfolio over the years at High-Yield Landlord.

data.title: QQQI Vs. QQQ: The Most Dangerous Bet In Mega-Cap Tech Right Now
data.description:
Over the past three months, NEOS Nasdaq-100 High Income ETF (QQQI) has outperformed the Invesco QQQ Trust (QQQ).

Even though QQQ has outperformed QQQI over the long term, it is not surprising that QQQI outperformed QQQ in recent months due to the way it is structured.

This is because QQQI combines the concentrated tech exposure that QQQ provides with an actively managed covered call overlay. As such, when tech stocks (XLK) are soaring, QQQ outperforms QQQI. However, in a market where they flounder, QQQI tends to outperform QQQ. Given that recently increasing caution has been put on mega-cap tech stocks due to their massive AI CapEx commitments this year with uncertain return profiles, and there are major concerns about valuations and AI disruption of the software industry, QQQ has been floundering, which means that the covered calls that QQQI employs are helping it to outperform by giving it additional cash flow without having to forfeit much, if anything, in the way of upside so far this year. This is exactly the type of environment where covered call strategies shine.

However, what about moving forward? Should investors continue to play QQQI, or should they switch back to QQQ, or perhaps should they avoid mega-cap tech altogether? In this article, I will break down QQQI in more detail and share my take on the stock.

The Structural Flaws That Could Undermine Long-Term Returns

I last wrote about QQQI back in December, when I highlighted how the yield looks great, and the performance looks great, yet there are some structural flaws that will lead to long-term total return underperformance. These include the relatively high expense ratio of 0.68%, the fact that its performance looks artificially good, given that, since its inception, its underlying index has performed very well, and it has only been in business a little over two years.

Additionally, while its monthly distributions and its high annual yield of over 1% per month in payouts look extremely attractive, its SEC yield is microscopic, which means that it is generating virtually all of its yield from premiums that it earns from writing covered calls against its underlying holdings. This means that nearly all of its distributions amount to a return of capital. Additionally, even while much is made of the active management and its ability to dynamically manage the portfolio to preserve upside during bull markets to keep the ETF from falling too far behind, even year to date with a relatively sideways to even declining QQQ, QQQI has still seen its principal decline by more than QQQ has, showing that even in a relatively ideal scenario, it can still see its NAV erode more than its underlying index. This shows that its options-writing strategy does consistently eat into the NAV.

Thus, you will need a long-term bull market in QQQ and avoid too much sharp volatility for QQQI to preserve and grow NAV over time on top of its attractive distributions. This is especially true given that its top holdings and its general portfolio construction closely mirror QQQs, so that gives it an underlying equity risk and overweight tech exposure that is essentially the same.

AI CapEx, Valuations, And The Shifting Macro Backdrop

The macro factors that have driven QQQIs strong total return performance over time are bullish for tech, which has also led to it underperforming QQQ. However, recently, it has outperformed QQQ because some of these factors have shifted, namely that AI enthusiasm is tempered somewhat, investors are now looking more closely at valuations as well as returns on massive AI CapEx investments, and software is increasingly being viewed through a critical lens as a likely candidate for disruption from AI innovations.

This means that QQQ has seen its performance weakened considerably relative to dividend stocks, as evidenced by the Schwab US Dividend Equity ETF (SCHD)s significant outperformance of QQQ over the past three months, while QQQI has only moderately tempered that weakness through its options-writing strategy and has still trailed SCHD by a huge margin over that time period.

Given that tech valuations remain far from what I would consider bargain territory and we are still early on in the AI CapEx cycle, as well as the potential for software disruption, I do not think that QQQ is at all appealing relative to QQQI right now. And so, therefore, if presented with the two and trying to gain things over a relatively short- to medium-term horizon, I would continue to favor QQQI and other NASDAQ-focused covered call ETFs.

However, there are important trade-offs that need to be kept in mind. First of all, if we were to see a material pullback of QQQ into correction territory, I would probably switch from QQQI to QQQ to avoid missing out on a strong bounce back, since covered calls would temper that and potentially lock in long-term losses.

Better Income Alternatives With Stronger Risk-Reward Profiles

Additionally, it is worth questioning whether you should have much exposure to any tech fund at all right now, given the valuations and macro factors already mentioned, especially since you can also buy dividend-paying stocks on a value basis that are enjoying macro tailwinds.

For example, you can buy several high-quality, investment-grade midstreams that are benefiting from AI CapEx and do not suffer from uncertain AI return risks as the mega-cap techs do, while generating, in some cases, up to a 9% yield and enjoying inflation-beating growth, while also trading at single-digit valuation multiples. Even in ETF format, you can buy the Alerian MLP ETF (AMLP) with a near 8% yield and a strong recent dividend growth history.

Additionally, you can buy high-yield funds like the Cohen & Steers Infrastructure Fund (UTF) that offer mid- to high-single-digit yields and even broader diversification across AI-related infrastructure. Moreover, you can buy high-quality, conservative, senior secured software lenders at deep discounts to NAV and dividend yields that compare very nicely with QQQIs while enjoying a steep discount to NAV and a more conservative profile in terms of exposure to software given their senior secured lending stance at loan-to-values of between the mid-teens and the 30s rather than having straight-up equity exposure to richly valued software companies that occupy a substantial portion of QQQ and QQQIs portfolios. Not only that, but you get these yields without the covered call caps on upside potential.

As a result, while I think that QQQI is a better play than QQQ in the current environment, I am steering clear of both in favor of much more attractively valued and risk-positioned opportunities in the midstream and software lending space in my 7-8% yielding, total return outperforming, and below-market beta portfolios at High Yield Investor.

data.title: Oddity Tech: Contrarian 'Buy' After Meta's Shock Craters Investors' Sentiment
data.description:
Oddity Tech Ltd. (ODD) is a personal care company with a digital-first direct-to-consumer (DTC) model. ODDs portfolio includes its own brands, Il Makiage, SpoiledChild, and the newer telehealth concept MethodIQ. Recently, the company has faced challenges with an abnormal spike in user acquisition costs tied to changes in Meta Platforms (META) ad delivery algorithms. Of course, this has cast doubts over ODDs underlying business model and long-term prospects. However, the stock is now trading at such a deep discount that I feel it could be worthwhile speculating with a small bullish position. Hence, I rate ODD a viable contrarian buy at these levels.

Online Beauty And Wellness

Oddity Tech Ltd. is a beauty and wellness company that sells online and direct-to-consumer. ODD was incorporated back in 2013 and is headquartered in Tel Aviv, Israel. Interestingly, the stock has been on a sharp decline since its 2025 highs. Its now down almost 85% since then, so I thought it was worthwhile taking a look at its investment appeal at these levels.

As a quick overview, ODDs business model relies on e-commerce using a direct-to-customer (DTC) approach. ODD sells beauty products through its digital platform, and most of its revenue is from online DTC sales. Other revenue streams represent a minor contribution, such as selling through a local Israeli channel and marketing affiliates. ODDs platform operates the companys own brands. And theyre also responsible for the development of these in-house brands for consumers.

Similarly, ODDs physical products are manufactured for third parties under contract. In that sense, their brand portfolio includes Il Makiage, SpoiledChild, and MethodIQ. Il Makiage is a beauty brand, best known for online shade-matching and complexion products. SpoiledChild is a brand focused on skin and hair, which is built around personalization. Lastly, MethodIQ is a newer brand concept described as a telehealth platform offering customized treatments in dermatology areas, such as acne, hyperpigmentation, and eczema.

Its also worth mentioning that ODD continues to focus on developing new brands. It has an internal brand incubator called New Ventures, launched in 2019, created to develop and test new product categories using ODDs technology, which includes data science for customer segmentation and product strategy. Likewise, this pipeline optimizes for responsive digital marketing for testing of ads and offers with creative iterations, as well as molecular discovery for screening potential ingredients. In fact, ODDs incubator also predicts the products properties and uses hyperspectral vision for capturing images to make more precise skin analysis for improved diagnostics.

On top of that, ODDs user experience with Web UX is supposed to increase conversion using personalization. These tools improve product matching, marketing efficiency, and product development. Plus, they use a layer of shared data that feeds across their platforms. The company states that theyve so far collected over 2 billion individual signals from 68 million users, like quiz answers, shade and skin inputs, browsing behavior, purchases, and others. And ODD flags this as a competitive advantage because, as more users generate data, this loops back into their machine learning models for better conversion, retention, and efficiency, which is at the core of their growth flywheel.

Valuation And Risk Analysis

Now, from a valuation perspective, ODD currently trades at a $790.7 million market cap. Its latest 6-K shows they ended 2025 with $402.2 million in cash and $373.7 million in marketable securities (short and long term). That amounts to approximately $775.9 million in liquid resources against $584.4 million in financial debt (exchangeable note). Using those figures, I estimate ODDs EV at roughly $599.2 million. And if we compare it to its Q4 revenues of $152.7 million (annualized $610.8 million), it implies a quite cheap EV/S of 1.0. For comparison, their sectors median EV/S is much closer to 1.5, so it would appear that investors are likely pricing in a major contraction in their topline or margin deterioration.

With that in mind, that brings us to ODDs recently significant abnormal increase in user acquisition cost (UAC). For a digital-first DTC company, paid ads are a core growth lever. If UAC spikes unexpectedly, growth can slow, and margins can compress. ODD also stated that the dislocation was tied to METAs changes related to its ad delivery and targeting algorithm. And naturally, this now casts doubts about ODDs platform risk and its dependence on META. After all, a good example of platform risk was Zynga, which was another rapidly growing company that relied heavily on META. Yet, after META implemented changes to its mobile gaming policies, Zyngas business quickly dwindled.

So its unsurprising to see that Wall Street downgraded ODD, and Bank of America warned that the problem is widespread, affecting acquisitions broadly across brands. Beauty is competitive, and if online acquisition becomes less efficient, brands with a strong retail presence may gain the upper hand in acquiring customers physically relative to online discovery. For example, companies like Sephora and Ulta, among others, don't rely as heavily on online channels.

Therefore, ODD could be at risk of losing considerable market share if it cant adapt and acquire new customers. But, historically, ODDs revenue and adjusted EBITDA growth have been consistent. And even if it were to level off at where it is today, it would suggest that ODD may be a viable contrarian buy despite the prevailing pessimistic sentiment. However, if I instead add their 2025 cash flows from operations and CAPEX (a cash burn proxy), it would appear ODD remains cash flow positive, but to a lesser extent. Using this approach, I estimate ODD generated approximately $83.6 million in 2025, which showcases theyre not in a death spiral stage just yet.

But its worth mentioning that, so far, Meta hasnt published a note explaining what they have changed in detail, which could help explain ODDs current conversion issues. ODD said that the algorithm diverted it to lower-quality auctions at abnormally high costs, meaning that ad placements convert less because they are directed to audiences that are less likely to buy. Moreover, auctions are not only less productive but also more expensive compared to historical performance.

In fact, ODD may need to diversify across channels with ads through Google, TikTok, affiliates, influencers, and partnerships to reduce its dependence on Meta. However, as you might imagine, these types of changes are structural and will likely require a longer repair cycle. ODD may even need to rethink its whole marketing strategy, as ads on Google work differently from ads on Facebook or Instagram. Also, according to Bank of America, a more concrete solution for ODDs marketing issues may take at least until 2027 to show results.

Conclusion: Cautious Contrarian Buy

Overall, I feel ODDs business is now definitely challenged. The reality is that we dont know yet the true extent of their problems that may arise from Metas recent policy changes. If we later learn that ODD can make a few tweaks and continue operating as usual, then I think the stock would bounce very quickly. On the other hand, if Metas changes are structural and require a fundamental pivot in the way ODD conducts its marketing strategy, then this contrarian Buy may take much longer to fully play out. However, at such a deep discount, I feel ODD is now worth speculating with a small bullish position at these levels. Just make sure you keep your position sizing under control.

data.title: How I Diagnose S&P 500 With Junk Bond Rates
data.description:
Junk bond yield is my depth indicator

We wrote an article a few days ago (titled These Flawed Arguments Can Be Especially Misguiding In 2026) and offered some counterarguments against bearish interpretation of the equity market based on high P/E ratios and substantial price rallies in recent years. After thinking over the issue for a few days, we felt that the analysis could use a follow-up. That analysis focused more on pointing out the flaws of common indicators such as high P/E without really offering alternative ideas to diagnose the market.

With this background, our goal in this article is quite simple. I will explain why and how I use junk bond rates as a leading signal for the equity market. Ive been experimenting with this idea for more than a decade by now, and my winning odds are good. The ideas apply to all major equity indices Ive experimented with (such as the DJI, SP500, and NASDAQ, and also small cap (RTY)). But for the sake of brevity, this article will use the SP500 index as the primary example.

I assume most investors can agree on the close relationship between corporate bonds and stocks. There are simply the two sides of the same coin. As such, I will focus my attention on explaining why I particularly like to use junk bonds but no other bonds (say, investment-grade bonds). In a nutshell, I am more interested in junk bond rates because A) they change more sensitively to corporate fundamentals, and B) they serve as a more effective depth indicator than bonds with better investment grades. In our experience, many (probably most) investors hold sizable bond positions of treasury and investment grade bonds regardless of market conditions. But due to their weaker credit ratings, junk bond rates change sensitivity to investors risk appetite. When junk bond yields are unusually low, it indicates to me that investors risk appetite has expanded to include assets with questionable financial strength. I am not usually too worried about assets with high quality (like the Mag 7) trading at high multiples. But when assets of sub-par qualities are also trading with a premium, I begin to be concerned.

With the above understanding, lets examine the current status of junk bond rates and analyze the implications for the SP500.

Historical perspective

To provide the perspective needed in this article, I first need to find junk rates data for a sufficiently long period of time. For the purpose, the chart below displays the dividend yield from the Vanguard High-Yield Corporate Fund Investor Shares (VWEHX). The VWEHX mutual fund is the oldest junk bond fund I can find, with data dating back to 1978, as seen.

Per the fund's latest discourse as of Dec 31, 2025 (see the next chart below), VWEHXs exposure is heavily concentrated in below-investment-grade corporate bonds. Its largest exposure is corporate bonds with BB credit ratings, which account for more than half of its total assets (51.5%). The second largest exposure is toward bonds with a B- credit rating, representing about 1/3 of its total assets (31.5%).

In the long term, the historical average of the funds yield is around 7.76%, as shown. The yield has dipped to as low as about 4.1% amid the epic easing during the COVID pandemic. The yield has climbed up substantially since then and is currently hovering around 6.18%. It is thus lower than the historical average, but not to an alarming degree. And we will further explore the implications next.

Junk bond yield as a leading signal

To explore the long-term effectiveness of junk bond yields as a leading signal for the equity market, I will need the long-term performance of an equity index fund. On this front, the oldest fund I can find is the Vanguard 500 Index Fund (VFIAX). As a fun fact, when John Bogle first launched the fund in 1976, the fund was mocked as "Bogle's Folly" because critics couldn't believe investors would settle for a fund that "only" provides average market returns by design.

Now, the top panel of the next chart shows the price movement of VFIAX in terms of price corrections off high. The bottom panel shows the yield spread of VWEHX relative to fed fund rates approximated by 3-month treasury rates. A quite clear correlation (that is, an inverse correlation) can be seen even from a visual examination between these two panels. The green and red arrows highlighted a few key market events that played a definitive role in the SP500s returns in the past 50 years or so. These key events included the formation and burst of the dot-com bubble, the 2008 financial crisis, the 2010 European bank crisis, the monetary easing following the COVID-19 breakout, and the subsequent tightening. As seen, amid all key junctures, when the junk bond rates are unusually low relative to risk-free rates, as indicated by the green arrows, the SP500 index suffered a sharp correction shortly afterward due to the fundamental dynamics mentioned in the first section. Such unusually low junk bond rates suggest that the markets risk appetite has swung too far to the greedy extreme. And the opposite is also true, as highlighted by the red arrows.

Other risks and final thoughts

If history does rhyme, you can see why I am not too alarmed by the current market conditions. As mentioned earlier, junk bond rates are currently below average but not alarmingly so. The current spread between VWEHX and 3-month treasury rates gave me a very similar assessment. As seen, the current yield spread sits at 2.492%. The bad news for equity investors is that it is below the historical average of 4.83%. The good news is that the spread has thickened considerably from its recent trough and is no longer alarmingly thin. Furthermore, the latest dot plot, announced by the Federal Open Market Committee in Dec 2025, shows a path of continued cuts to the fed fund rates in the near future. As you can see from the following screenshot, the dot plot suggests the median expectation of the fed funds rate to decrease from the current level of around 3.6% to around 3.0% in 2027. With everything else being equal, such a decrease could further thicken the yield spread between VWEHX and 3-month treasury rates to about 3.1%.

To close, the goal of this article is mainly twofold. First, I want to offer an alternative idea, the use of junk bond rates, for investors to diagnose the equity (beyond P/E ratios and rolling-returns in past years). Second, I want to apply this idea to the current market conditions. My diagnosis is that current junk bond rates certainly are on the lower end and worth closely monitoring. But I do not believe it is to an alarming degree to trigger a dramatic departure from the SP500 or other equity index.
